required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Modified Diabetes Prevention Program in Ecuador
clinical_study.official_title: A Pilot of a Modified Diabetes Prevention Program in Quito, Ecuador

brief_summary.textblock: This pilot study will evaluate the use of a modified (cultural and language) adaptation of the National Diabetes Prevention Program in a cohort in Quito Ecuador.

detailed_description.textblock:
This pilot study will evaluate the use of a modified (cultural and language) adaptation of the National Diabetes Prevention Program in a cohort in Quito Ecuador.
Adaptations- the coaches will be physicians from PUCE and they will administer this program for eligible employees who have biochemical prediabetes.
The program will be modified to be able to fit within the school curriculum. The diabetes prevention program will be offered in Spanish and the content modified to better fit the cultural norms for the Quito Ecuador population.
Participants will be adults with prediabetes as screened by the CDC Diabetes Risk Test and confirmed by HbA1c.
Outcome measures will include change in mean HbA1c, change in weight, physical activity, and attendance to the program.

secondary_outcome.description: change in weight over the 6 month program

intervention.description: This program is a 1 year lifestyle modification program focused on reducing calories and fat calories and increasing physical activity to achieve a 7% weight loss. This study utilized the first 16 sessions (6 months) of the program

study_pop.textblock: The faculty and staff at PUCE University in Quito Ecuador were invited to participate in the study.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria: Adults who worked at the university and had biochemical prediabetes.
-
Exclusion Criteria: Those with known diabetes, those unwilling to complete a 6 month intervention.
-

patient_data.ipd_description: We will not share any patient identifier information with anyone outside the study.
